intro: Scirpus savii var. major, commonly known as the greater tussock sedge, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to wetland and marshy environments in Europe and parts of Asia. It typically grows to a height of 60–100 cm, with tall, cylindrical stems and dense, grass-like leaves. The plant produces small, three-lobed flowers in spikes, which are usually greenish or reddish in color. It thrives in moist, nutrient-poor soils and is often found in peat bogs and fens. Scirpus savii var. major plays an important ecological role in stabilizing wetland soils and providing habitat for various invertebrates and birds.
